title: Which is grammatically correct: “I am writing” or “I write”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both are grammatically correct and serve different purposes I am writing is present continuous and simply indicates an actually ongoing action — what I am currently doing at this point on the time axis.I write is more blurred on the time axis and does not indicate what I am doing at this particular moment, but used such as in the statement: I write for a living.So just now I am writing this answer to you, but as I am not a professional writer I cannot say I write for a living.

Both are correct. Here’s a quirk about the English language: Often the present tense isn’t used for present time. Picture this situation: You ask a friend what she’s doing right now. She says, “I write.” Nope! No native speaker would ever say that. She would say, “I’m writing.” “I write” doesn’t mean “I’m writing at the present moment.” It means “I write continuously” or “I often write.” My husband writes gardening columns for a newspaper. He’s writing a column right now. The same applies to most present-tense verbs. (The verb “to be” does signify right now: “I’m a teacher.”)
